docs.snippet: Responding to Web critics, Google has modified its Reader service to allow users to choose the people who have access to their list of favorite blog items....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, Google caused a bit of a furor when it expanded the sharing capabilities of Google Reader, the company's service for viewing blogs. The main complaint was that Google assumed that anyone you had exchanged messages with using Google Talk was your friend. If those people were Google Reader users, they would be able to see any item you marked as "shared."

headline.main: Google Now Allows You to Pick Your Friends in Reader

docs.abstract: Responding to Web critics, Google has modified its Reader service to allow users to choose the people who have access to their list of favorite blog items.

docs.snippet: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as "white spaces," will be unused after TV statio...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google and other technology giants like Microsoft, Intel and Dell, have long pushed for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum to be used to provide new high-speed wireless Internet access networks. The airwaves, known as "white spaces," will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.

headline.main: Google Starts an Advocacy Campaign for More Unlicensed Spectrum

docs.abstract: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as "white spaces," will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.

docs.snippet: Even without its 2006 purchase of YouTube and its 2004 purchase of Picasa, Google has made substantial inroads into several online categories. Google Maps, above showing Miami Beach in satellite view, had a 31 percent share in July, compared with ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Even without its 2006 purchase of YouTube and its 2004 purchase of Picasa, Google has made substantial inroads into several online categories. Google Maps, above showing Miami Beach in satellite view, had a 31 percent share in July, compared with 46 percent for Mapquest, the maps category leader that preceded it online by nine years. (Google Earth, with a 1.8 percent share, is also in the maps category.) Blogger is second to MySpace Blog, which has a 22.4 percent share, but its share is double that of LiveJournal, No. 3 in the blogs/personal category, at 3.4 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline.main: Popular Demand

docs.abstract: Chart shows top 10 share of visits in Web categories for July; drawing (S)

docs.snippet: ROBBINS--Martha. Congregation Ohav Sholom, Merrick, deeply mourns the passing of a founding stalwart member and past officer. Martha, by her very presence, exuded a quiet sense of dignity, decorum and intelligence. We extend our condolences to Ber...
docs.lead_paragraph: ROBBINS--Martha. Congregation Ohav Sholom, Merrick, deeply mourns the passing of a founding stalwart member and past officer. Martha, by her very presence, exuded a quiet sense of dignity, decorum and intelligence. We extend our condolences to Bert and the Robbins family. She will be sorely missed. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg Brian Bertan, President ROBBINS--Martha Farkas. Our wife, mother, mother-inlaw and grandmother, Martha Farkas Robbins, who was devoted to her family and its matriarch and historian, died on August 24 at the age of 85. Committed to Judaism, she lived her life guided by its values and invigorated by its intellectualism, fostering its strains of feminism and fighting its strains of dogmatism. Though short in physical stature, she was a towering presence. A college professor and voracious reader, she had an encyclopedic memory and boundless curiosity. In fact, she was such a Renaissance woman that even in this age of Google, her grandchildren, when faced with a question, often said, ''I'll call Grandma.'' She was passionate about politics (an unwavering Democrat); a devotee of opera and talented if intermittent pianist; an avid traveler; and an incomparable cook. We will greatly miss her infinite wisdom, quiet elegance, unfailing perfectionism and, most of all, her deep love of family and friends that shone through all she did. She is survived by her devoted husband Norbert, her children Bill and Naomi and their spouses Patti and Mark, and her grandchildren Ben, Ilana, Hannah and Jeremy.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBBINS, MARTHA
